reviewText: [ONCE YOU KISS A STRANGER - (1969) - Widescreen presentation - directed by Robert Sparr]  The movie: A second-rate knock-off of Hitchcock's classic 'Strangers on a Train', only this time out, it takes place on a golf course. An irresistible blonde cherub with a pathological past and a plan for the perfect murder sets up a golf pro to take the fall or succumb to her diabolical endeavor. The plot stutters and drags periodically, it's about ten minutes too long, all characters /actors except the leading lady are immediately forgettable, and the film has the utilitarian directorial tone of an 'ABC Movie-of-the-Week' feel to it, as stated by another reviewer. That said, it IS a wicked slice of campy 60's cinematic cheese that will certainly find its deserving audience. In other words, I loved it. Here's why -The Leading Lady: Carol Lynley ('Bunny Lake is Missing') has found the perfect vehicle for herself here depicting the insidious siren who is temptation personified and deviously disturbed and demented, scorching every celluloid frame she appears in. From the first scene, she establishes the tone of her character and subsequently sets the bar higher and higher in terms of reinforcing the 'fun' in dysfunctional depravity and deception. She never looked better; radiantly tanned, hair short to frame her adorable face perfectly, wearing cute little outfits that accentuate her fantastically fit figure, behaving salaciously - just the type of woman you'd gladly throw your life away for, with little or no regret. Her character is the embodiment of evil, and what she does with her dialogue and actions will give you chills, make you laugh at her wickedness and ultimately beg for more. She carries the weight of the entire film on her slender little back effortlessly, which begs one to wonder why she never became more insanely popular, especially in the 70's when nearly-every two-bit hag in Hollywood with a modicum of talent was making box-office headlines.As a movie, this one falters yet has certain deceptive charms and redeeming moments, mostly for those who appreciate 60's cinema and second-tier psychological murder and thriller tales. As a vehicle for Carol Lynley and her fan base, stand up and rejoice over the fact that Warner Bros. Archive has finally dusted off this kitschy Hitchcockian knock-off for a small but rabid audience. This is no more than a three star flick I'm bumping up to four stars due to the reasons I've detailed. Go ahead, doom yourself to 'Once You Kiss a Stranger'...you just might be glad you did.
summary: Carol Lynley Salvages This Film Single-Handedly...

reviewText: I enjoyed this movie when I saw it some years ago and it did not disappoint this time around either. It is a relevant story even today. Paul Burke was a favorite of mine. A timeless story, well written with excellent performances from his co-stars make this movie one of my all time favorites.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Finally available on DVD from WB Archives' Manufacture-on-Demand program, "Once You Kiss a Stranger" is the 1969 remake of Hitchcock's "Strangers on a Train".I really wanted to like this movie better than I did--it just sounded so much better on paper than what the end product turned out to be.Part of the problem is that much of it is set at a golf tournament, and IMO watching golf is as exciting as watching paint dry.Lovely but psychotic Carol Lynley is on the verge of being committed to an asylum by her psychiatrist and elderly rich aunt and so she decides to concoct a plan to avoid being put away. She beds pro golfer Paul Burke and afterwards suggests they "swap" murders: She'll off his chief golf rival if he disposes of that persky doctor of hers. Of course, Burke blows her suggestion off as a simple but warped "game", but then his rival turns up dead on the green the next morning!The rest of the film has Burke avoiding the police, dealing with his marital problems with his wife (a somewhat bloated Martha Hyer) and trying to stay a step ahead of Lynley.While the story and acting are average and nothing to rave about, the print looks fab and the film is very colorful and a great time capsule, with lots of exterior shots of late '60s cars and Malibu location shooting. Lynley looks amazing in her beach scenes wearing a green bikini. She threatens a child with her harpoon, shoves a cat in her refrigerator, films her sexual encounters with a video camera hidden in her purse and chases Hyer all over the beach in a dune buggy.There are some familiar faces in the picture such as Philip Carey who plays the golf rival and was the gay football player in that memorable "All in the Family" episode "Judging Books By Covers"."Once You Kiss a Stranger" is an okay watch but not as good as other psychological thrillers of the era such as "Whatever Happened to Aunt Alice", etc. Rent before you buy.
summary: Late '60s Time Capsule Not as Good as It Could've Been

reviewText: According to the imdb, the aspect ratio is 1.66:1.If the info on amazon is correct and the dvd is 1.77 then it is obviously cropped.  In that case you will miss parts of Carol in her bikini.ANY OLD MOVIE LISTED AS 1.77 AKA 16X9 IS WRONG!!!16x9 is a modern compromize between 35mm and 70mm film.They should always produce dvd's without cropping for modern formats.  I don't mind haveing a little black on the sides in order to see the entire frame.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Patricia Highsmith's novel and Alfred Hitchcock's film of 'STRANGERS ON A TRAIN' gets a late sixties makeover in Director Robert Sparr's 'ONCE YOU KISS A STRANGER', an odd, low budget affair which resembles an old ABC-TV Movie of the Week entry but misses the mark because of its sleaze factor. Carol Lynley plays Diana, a nutzoid who was in and out of mental institutions since the age of 13 and has a major bone to pick with her psychiatrist. She sets her offbeat sights on Jerry played by Paul Burke, a down on his luck pro golfer who is kept from being champ by arrogant Mike played by Phil Carey.  By seducing Jerry in a drunken one night stand, she tapes them in coitus and his consent to swap the murders of their particular enemies.  This sets up the films running time of how Jerry tries to get out of his sand trap.  Besides Phil Carey, the film has many B-movie familiar faces such as Martha Hyer, Whit Bisell, and Stephen McNally in a rare good guy role as a police detective.  The photography is by Psychotronic film stalwart Jacques Marquette who also filmed the awesome Allison Hayes in  'ATTACK OF THE 50FT WOMAN' and directed the great Universal Pictures B actress Anne Gwynne in 'TEENAGE MONSTER' both in the fifties.  It also has a great jazzy Lounge music score by Jimmy Fagas which almost makes the film feel like an Italian Giallo entry sometimes.  But the film belongs to Carol Lynley who never looked more beautiful and ignites the screen in every scene she's in. The film may be a bit lengthy clocking in at 107 minutes but Warner Archive gives it a beautiful 1.85 widescreen transfer with rich colors and clear sound which makes it a worthy sixties entry to be rediscovered.
Title: N/A
